description: Moderate - Entry is easier than research/academic paths, but building sustainable income requires 2-3 years of experience, strong portfolio, self-discipline, and business skills

fresher: *Note: As a freelancer, you define your own title. Common designations on profiles/business cards

dailyWork: *Note: Freelance work varies significantly based on clients and projects. Here's a typical breakdown
Coding and developing client projects (4-6 hours/day of focused work)
Responding to client messages and feedback

learningCurve.description: **Moderate** - The technical skills are similar to employment (coding, problem-solving), but freelancing adds a business layer: finding clients, writing proposals, managing projects, handling finances. First 6-12 months are steep (low income, learning client management). After 1-2 years, it becomes more predictable. The challenge is discipline (no boss), irregular income (feast and famine cycles), and constantly finding next client. Easiest after 2-3 years of employment experience (you have skills, portfolio, and network to start).

factors: Income uncertainty: Irregular income, feast and famine cycles
Constant client hunting: Always need to find next project
No safety net: No PTO, sick leave, severance (you don't work = no income)
Client management stress: Difficult clients, scope creep, late payments
Isolation: Solo work, no team collaboration (can be lonely)
mitigatingFactors: Autonomy: You're the boss, control your schedule
Flexibility: Work from anywhere, choose your hours
Choose clients: Say no to bad clients (eventually)
Higher income potential: Can earn more than employment (top freelancers)

thriveIf: You're self-disciplined and don't need external structure
You're comfortable with income variability (some months high, some low)
You're good at self-promotion and networking
You enjoy autonomy and making your own decisions
You're comfortable wearing many hats (dev + sales + admin)
You like variety (different clients, projects, technologies)
You're organized and can manage multiple projects
avoidIf: You prefer team collaboration and daily interactions
You struggle with self-discipline and motivation
You're uncomfortable with sales and self-promotion
You need clear structure and defined work hours

collegeStrategy.title: Build Technical Foundation
goals: Learn full-stack web development (React, Node.js, databases)
Understand basics of freelancing (read blogs, watch videos)

collegeStrategy.title: Expand Skills + First "Clients"
goals: Learn additional tech stacks (mobile, cloud, different frameworks)
Build more complex projects (full-stack apps, APIs)
Offer services to friends, family, local businesses (₹5-20k projects, portfolio building)
Learn to write proposals (practice on sample projects)

collegeStrategy.title: Serious Side Hustle
goals: Start bidding on Upwork/Freelancer projects (small projects ₹10-30k)
Learn client communication and project management
Summer internship: Work at company to build experience (₹30-60k/month)

collegeStrategy.title: Decide: Job First or Freelance
goals: *Recommended Path A (Safer): Job First, Then Freelance
Work 2-3 years, build expertise and savings
